before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"ccd51","text":"You will need access to the following free and open-source software program(s):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"921r3","text":"minimap2","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":8}],"data":[]},{"key":"3lfl2","text":"samtools","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":8}],"data":[]},{"key":"a0vkt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2qjvn","text":"And the following additional data file(s):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eu5i1","text":"a FASTA file containing the genome / sequence of interest.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"7A236DEC469243DD91BE6819DABD7798","url":"https://github.com/lh3/minimap2#install"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"068394FAB0BA4A47B41E27F9B391D23F","url":"http://www.htslib.org/download/"}}}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"fhvce","text":"This protocol demonstrates how to map strand-oriented long reads to a genome, and visualise them in a genome browser.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f9jcf","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7fu3m","text":"The general idea is to use minimap2 to create stranded BAM files, which are split for forward/reverse orientation then converted into BigWig format for display in a genome browser.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a795b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eqpbd","text":"Input(s): ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dbtho","text":"stranded fastq files (see protocol Preparing Reads for Stranded Mapping)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":35,"length":36}],"data":[]},{"key":"8dnu1","text":"a FASTA file containing the genome / sequence of interest.\n ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6ojic","text":"Output(s):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"avnru","text":"Genome-mapped stranded BAM files","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bjr0k","text":"Genome-mapped stranded BigWig files","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"CD9E2910661D11E9BF52E752A6ECEFB5","url":"https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.57hg9j6"}}}}

groups.title: High molecular weight DNA extraction from all kingdoms

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

{"blocks":[{"key":"bo85s","text":"Map the long reads to the genome using minimap2, using samtools to covert to a sorted BAM format. This is where the reverse complementing done during demultiplexing gives a big saving of effort. As this BAM file is one of the main outputs, the run name is added to the file name.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a3m3f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9bdpr","text":" {"blocks":[{"key":"brg3p","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2pk7g","text":"A bedGraph of coverage is created using samtools mpileup and mpileupDC.pl, excluding any skipped intronic sequence. When 'mpileupDC.pl' is provided with a single file, it will output a bedGraph file with a header line starting with '##'; this header line is removed. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":61,"length":12}],"data":{}},{"key":"d0qep","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b55h","text":"To simplify output naming in later steps, the run name is added to the file name.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4enql","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1lt88","text":"The particular JBrowse plugin that I use for stranded display requires that the reverse strand have negative coverage values, so that file needs to be changed:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":100,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"19igc","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4857p","text":"As an alternative, BEDTools can be used to generate coverage. The default options for BEDTools treat sequence deletions (which happen frequently in nanopore reads) as a drop in coverage, which can make exon hunting and coverage calculation more difficult. I submitted a pull request to add an additional ignoreD parameter to the command line to allow cDNA reads with split coverage across introns to ignore deletions when considering coverage; this request has now been incorporated into the main BEDtools repository (as of v2.30.0):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":304,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":268,"length":14}],"data":{}},{"key":"6iqde","text":" {"blocks":[{"key":"st01","text":"Each track should have its own JBrowse configuration section using the StrangedBigWig class and StrandedXYPlot type. BAM tracks can also be added. An example is shown here:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":71,"length":14},{"style":"italic","offset":96,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bcsr0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"39udc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7b0jl","text":"[tracks.BWCG004-4T1-BC04-both-track ] storeClass     = StrandedPlotPlugin/Store/SeqFeature/StrandedBigWig urlTemplate    = bw/mm2_called_CG004_BC04_vs_MmusG.bw category       = MinION - Coverage type           = StrandedPlotPlugin/View/Track/Wiggle/StrandedXYPlot key            = MinION minimap2 coverage from CG004-4T1-WT (combined strands) scale          = log scoreType      = maxScore autoscale      = global style.pos_color = darkred style.neg_color = darkgreen","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":440},{"key":1,"offset":440,"length":27}],"data":[]},{"key":"tgg6","text":"I have written my own helper scripts to reduce the effort required to generate these track sections. This is specific to my use case, but may help others for adapting to their own use. It takes three command-line parameters: the base file name, the internal ID for use in the track definition, and the label that appears within JBrowse. I use it as follows:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"38a9p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fpvjc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4o2me","text":" {"blocks":[{"key":"3rk17","text":"If this has worked properly, then mapping human or mouse to the mitochondrial genome should show most expression appearing on the positive strand, with a small scattering of negative-strand expression, a bit like the Expected Results shown here.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":217,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fje26","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"66c92","text":"If not, check for the following issues:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bcrjq","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f3uuc","text":"Tracks not displaying at all in JBrowse -- make sure track IDs inside square brackets are of the form [ tracks.\u003cunique-id-without-dots\u003e-track ]","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":104,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3t67d","text":"JBrowse track is reflected in the X axis -- make sure that the reverse bedgraph file is orientated the correct way; it should be created with the '-f 0x10' flag (no capitalisation).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2rvp0","text":"JBrowse track only shows one direction -- make sure that the reverse bedgraph file has negative values, and re-generate the bigwig file","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":87,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"343lk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5cjtf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"9c7ef","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"result","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"n1fh","text":"  ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fhi4k","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"9A3CD39011C111EBAEB58BB472A28524","height":244,"id":215934,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9uqn0","text":"Stranded BigWig JBrowse tracks for four samples, demonstrating log expression on the mitochondrial chromosome.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"JBrowse_mtDNA.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/d3caf5d2f980d165712bb8262c51687a45460e9aedd9631ff736620da233c966/cnn8jpt6.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gu58jpt6.jpg","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gu57jpt6.webp","width":550},"mutability":"","type":"image"}}}}}}
